Chapter 7, Part 3: The Assembly of Armored Adornments
Furthermore, Anantamati!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas set out for the realm of boundless armor, the realm of the boundless Great Vehicle, and the realm of the boundless great path.
Why is this?
Because they are able to follow and enter everywhere.

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas don the great armor in order to follow and enter all dharmas, they ride the Great Vehicle in order to follow and enter all dharmas, they abide in this great path in order to follow and enter all dharmas, and they set out for the sake of attaining equality in all dharmas.

However, this armor does not obtain even the slightest dharma, whether internal or external, coarse or subtle, far or near, past, present, or future, conditioned or unconditioned, abiding or non-abiding.

If this armor cannot discern, determine, thoroughly know, follow, realize, or transcend all dharmas, it cannot be called the great armor.ğŸ”½If it can discern, determine, thoroughly know, follow, realize, and transcend all dharmas, then it can be called the great armor.

Moreover, this Great Vehicle also has no dharmas, whether internal or external, up to dedicating them to omniscience, thoroughly knowing, following, realizing, and transcending them. Therefore, this vehicle is called the Great Vehicle, the skillful means vehicle, the vehicle reaching nirvana, the unsurpassed vehicle, and the unequaled vehicle.

Moreover, this great path also has no dharmas, whether internal or external, up to being able to set out on the great path of all dharmas, this great path of equanimity has no dharmas that are not thoroughly known, therefore this path is called the unsurpassed path, the path of immeasurable quantity, the path of unequaled equality.
Anantamati!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas don the great armor and are able to follow and enter the mental activities of all sentient beings everywhere, are able to purify the defiled afflictions of all sentient beings everywhere, ride the great vehicle, and increase the wholesome roots of all sentient beings. Abiding in this great path, they exhort and transform sentient beings in all wholesome dharmas.
Anantamati!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for each and every sentient being, for each and every mental activity, exhaust the limits of birth and deathğŸ”½and for a long time revolve [in saá¹ƒsÄra], seeking the joy of wisdom and not abandoning the armor, and are able to firmly don the great
armor.

Anantamati!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not don this armor, do not follow awakening, do not decisively understand, do not escape, and do not realize it. Because there is no armor, they don the armor; because they do not follow awakening, they are able to follow awakening; because they do not decisively understand, they are able to decisively understand; because they do not escape, they are able to escape; because they do not realize, they are able to realize. Because they have nothing to ride, they ride the Great Vehicle. They do not establish the Great Vehicle, and they establish what is not established. However, there is not the slightest establishment in the Great Vehicle. If there is establishment, it is not establishment, because that establishment cannot be attained and cannot be seen.

There is also no vehicle to ride in to abide, but by not attaining anything one abides in the Great Vehicle, far removed from heading towards it, not reaching the ultimate, not arriving at nirvÄá¹‡a, because it cannot be attained, the non-path becomes the path.
Because this level path is advanced on the path, this level path is not established. By whom is it established?
Where is it established?
From where is it established?
There is also no action, no actor, neither in combination nor not in combination, completely detached from everything, not seeking anything.
Why is this?
This level path is neither different nor the same as all dharmas, because it is not associated with them.

Not giving rise to the notion of dharmas, detached from all dharmas, without defilement and without purity, the nature of dharmas is also like this, without defilement and without purity. Therefore, this path is called the unstained path, advanced by that which cannot be advanced towards, taken up by that which cannot be taken up.

This path is extremely profound, without birth or arising, without emergence or creation, without attainment or practice, without location or abiding, without obstruction or affairs, yet able to manifest all affairs, without distinction in all affairs, not following affairs, and due to the absence of affairs, reaching the unsurpassed place.
Boundless Wisdom!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should understand this armor, this vehicle, and this path in this way.
However, this armor, this vehicle, and this path are not to be seen or known, because they cannot be obtained.
Who is the one who dons the armor?
Who rides this vehicle?
Who practices this path?
Also, it cannot be seen, known, or obtained.
Boundless Wisdom!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having heard this teaching, are not startled or frightened, but read, recite, and expound it, not contradicting the principles of the Dharma, but practicing in accordance with them with joy and understanding, they should diligently strive for this teaching;

If one is able to skillfully understand the definitive principles of this teaching, wearing this armor, riding this vehicle, and practicing this path, because there is nothing to attain in this profound teaching, one who sets out for the end of the shore of birth and death to become a perfect buddha will be able to appear in the world adorned with boundless merit and virtue.
Infinite Wisdom!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should give rise to joy in this teaching, arouse great diligence, and be heedful.

If there are sentient beings who merely give rise to joy in this profound teaching, I say that those people will attain great benefit, let alone those who are diligent, heedful, and set out with pure precepts.
Infinite Wisdom!

You should observe that this Dharma is of various vastnesses, various distinctions, and various purities. I earnestly praise this Dharma, wishing to cause sentient beings to give rise to love and delight, to attain long-lasting benefit and peace, for the sake of disgust and detachment, for the sake of quiescence and cessation, for the sake of complete understanding.
Infinite Wisdom!
You should further observe that this Dharma can bestow upon the world both worldly and supramundane complete peace and happiness.
All those sentient beings who lack and are deficient, due to their regression from this profound Dharma, are far removed from all worldly and supramundane complete abundance and peace and happiness.
Infinite Wisdom!

You should further observe that the TathÄgata's present profound Dharma treasure is of various abundances and various easiness of attainment. You should now diligently cultivate and practice this profound Dharma.
Those foolish people, even when I expound this Dharma treasure, still do not wish to listen, let alone be able to uphold it. The TathÄgata's present Dharma treasure is abundant,
They do not enjoy listening and do not wish to inquire.

If in the final five hundred years of the Dharma's end, when the true Dharma is being destroyed, the Buddha, the Dharma Jewel, and those who uphold the Dharma are not present, how can they wish to hear and love to inquire?
Infinite Wisdom!
However, at that later time, if one is well upheld by the TathÄgata, this profound Dharma Jewel can also be attained.
Infinite Wisdom!

At that time of fear, this profound Dharma Jewel is truly not diminished or extinguished, but there are none who listen to it or uphold it, except for those who thirst to hear it in my presence and don the armor, who at that time will be able to love and accept this Dharma.

When beings hear this Dharma and give rise to pure faith, I say that they will attain accomplishment in this vast Dharma, let alone those who now give rise to pure faith and diligently practice this Dharma.
Infinite Wisdom!
When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas don the unsurpassed armor, the immeasurable armor, and the great armor, they should think like this:

I will, for all beings who lack, namely those who lack in morality, those who lack in learning, those who lack in wisdom, those who lack in liberation, and those who lack in the knowledge and insight of liberation, make them replete with this great Dharma.
Because of this great Dharma being made replete, all lack will be made to be abandoned.
The wealth of morality, the wealth of learning, the wealth of wisdom, the wealth of liberation, and the wealth of the knowledge and insight of liberation will all be made abundant;

The fires of greed, hatred, and delusion will all be made to cease, all illnesses will be made to be cured, and the unsurpassed good medicine will be made to be taken. By taking this medicine, all illnesses will be eliminated, and one will attain great peace and bliss, forever leaving no remainder. One will realize the supremely cool nature of nirvÄá¹‡a, and there will be no further conceptualization or investigation, and one will not seek any conditioned or unconditioned things.
Why is it so?
Because this nirvana is the supreme bliss, and there is no other seeking beyond it, and the seeking is eternally stilled and extinguished.
Anantamati!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having donned this great armor, also ride this great vehicle out of compassion and to embrace all beings.

This great vehicle is what the buddhas of the past have already ridden to liberation, what the buddhas of the future will ride to liberation, and what the buddhas of the present are riding to liberation.
There is no one who goes, nor is there any riding or liberation.
Why is it so?
Because of emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, non-arising, and non-action, there is no liberation in the past, no liberation in the present, and no liberation in the future.
One who rides this vehicle thus attains liberation, which is good liberation without attachment.
In all dharmas, there is neither union nor non-union, neither coming nor going.
When departing from this vehicle and this path, it is also non-coalescence, without coming or going.
When departing from this great armor through this vehicle and this path, it is also non-coalescence, neither coalescence nor non-coalescence, without coming or going, because it cannot be attained.
Anantamati!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas set out with this armor, this vehicle, and this path.
Moreover, when setting out with this armor, this vehicle, and this path, they do not think like this:
'Whether it is the Dharma of ordinary beings, the Dharma of Å›rÄvakas, the Dharma of pratyekabuddhas, or the Dharma of buddhas, that Dharma is neither far nor near to me.'
They also do not think like this:
'Whether it is emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, non-arising, or non-action, that Dharma is neither far nor near to me.'
They also do not think like this:
'Whether it is disgust, detachment, cessation, up to great parinirvÄá¹‡a, that Dharma is neither far nor near to me.'
Infinite Wisdom!
This great armor, this vehicle, this path, cannot be moved by any bodhisattva, any Å›rÄvaka, any pratyekabuddha, or any sentient being, yet they set out for supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Infinite Wisdom!
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, having attained immovability in this armor, this vehicle, this path, enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is this?

Because all dharmas are unmoving, because the nature of all dharmas and the characteristics of dharmas are far removed from characteristics, because they are pure by nature, and because they are universally pure.
They cannot be observed, excellently observed, or observed everywhere by means of characteristics.
The characteristics of all dharmas and the nature of the characteristics of dharmas cannot be observed, excellently observed, or observed everywhere by means of their nature.
All dharmas are without nature and without characteristics, they cannot be revealed, and cannot be spoken of. This is the true nature and characteristics of all dharmas.
Boundless Wisdom!
The true characteristics of this armor, this vehicle, and this path cannot be revealed, and cannot be spoken of, it is also like this.
In order to cause sentient beings to understand, and in order to increase the light of all dharmas, this armor, this vehicle, and this path are provisionally established and briefly explained.

If you now wish to practice in accordance with the meaning of this armor, this vehicle, and this path, do not provisionally establish, do not reveal, do not speak, but should practice in accordance with the meaning.
Practicing in accordance with the meaning means not practicing a little, not following a little.
If it is not the meaning, one should not follow it; if it is this meaning, then one should follow it.

When practicing according to the meaning, one does not practice according to sound, according to letters, according to words, and does not practice according to what is not practiced, and does not follow their transformations.
What is the meaning?
It refers to secret teachings.
Regarding secret teachings, one should awaken to them and practice with faith.
Those who practice with faith have no discrimination regarding this meaning, and in the absence of discrimination, one should practice accordingly.
Those who should practice accordingly do not practice, nor do they follow that practice.
Why is it so?
Because in this meaning there is no practice at all, no following of practice at all, no thorough practice at all, because practice is far removed.

One should not practice according to what is not practiced, nor should one practice according to what is not practiced. One should not practice according to the characteristics of enlightenment, nor should one practice according to the characteristics of saá¹ƒsÄra. Regarding those characteristics of practice and non-practice, one should not attend to them, and one should not be rightly mindful of them, because mindfulness is pure. Therefore, one should not practice.
Anantamati!
In this meaning, you should practice accordingly without being different from practice. If you practice differently, it will be a false loss.
Following sounds, following words, following language, one is unable to let go of those languages.
Thoroughly knowing sounds, transcending words, and following the awakening of language, one does not follow, does not flow.
In this meaning, such practice and such entry are without the slightest practice, because practice has ceased.
Boundless Wisdom!
When practicing the meaning, do not again practice the meaning with practice.
If one does not practice the meaning with practice, then one does not come and does not return again.
If one attains not coming and not returning again, then in this armor, this vehicle, this path, one follows and proceeds to supreme perfect enlightenment, greatly benefiting all beings.
Boundless Wisdom!

If one explains this teaching in this way, practices in accordance with the meaning, and is able to penetrate it, one's mind will be non-inverted, free from doubt, and endowed with superior understanding.
If one has not yet taken up this armor, this vehicle, and this path, one will be able to quickly take them up and set out;
if there are those who have not yet donned this armor, one will be able to quickly don it;ğŸ”½if there are those who have not yet mounted this vehicle, one will be able to quickly mount it;
if there are those who have not yet abided in this path, one will be able to quickly abide in it.
Anantamati!
Those beings will gather vast merit and virtue, be protected and remembered by the Buddha, be in accord with the Dharma, and practice together with the Sangha.
Anantamati!

You have already gathered immeasurable wholesome roots. In the latter age, you will use this Dharma to gather beings, bear the heavy burden for beings, and the merit and virtue you will obtain will be difficult to describe.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The fearless bodhisattvas, when they don the armor in this way,
Do so in order to benefit all beings, donning boundless armor.
If beings are poor and lacking, suffering and without the wealth of the Dharma,
Without precepts, without much learning, without wisdom, without liberation;
Wearing this boundless armor, they cause the Dharma to become abundant,
And because of the abundance of the Dharma, all attain peace and joy.
In order to abandon all poverty and suffering, they expound the unsurpassed Dharma,
And those who hear it all depart from defilements, abiding in this peaceful and joyful path.
The aggregate of precepts is fully sufficient, and much learning is like the great ocean,
One then attains the supreme wisdom, and by this, one is able to sever the bonds.
Liberation universally illuminates, and liberation is the right knowledge and vision,
If one is able to realize it, all attain peace and joy.
The great fires of greed, hatred, and delusion constantly burn and blaze everywhere,
Sentient beings suffer because of this, I will extinguish that fire for them.
I will give medicine to all sentient beings, curing all illnesses,
If illnesses are eliminated, they will attain the realm of nirvana.
Forever abandoning all else, they will go to a place of peace and joy,
From that place of peace and joy, there is no one who turns back.
All conditioned pleasures, they will not seek them again,
The unsurpassed great bliss, they will all realize it.
Using the Dharma free from conceptual proliferation, they will bring sentient beings to maturity,
Ultimately attaining the great bliss, all will obtain it.
Those who set out in this way, go forth once and do not return,
Surpassing those who have set out, they always attain supreme bliss.
Within the great bliss, whether one desires it or not,
Setting out and not setting out, all will be cut off.
Having thus donned the armor, one should ride this vehicle,
Out of compassion for all beings, to take them all in.ğŸ”½The Perfectly Awakened Ones of the past have already departed by this vehicle,
The Perfectly Awakened Ones of the future will depart by this vehicle,
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones of the present, are now departing by this vehicle,
Therefore, there is none who does not ride this Great Vehicle.
All the most excellent ones, the world's great reliance and support,
Depart by this vehicle, yet do not give rise to the notion of a vehicle,
Taking the non-vehicle as the vehicle, the non-path as the path,
Taking the non-departure as the departure, therefore it is unsurpassed.
When this vehicle departs, there is never any departure,
Because of emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, and non-action.
The non-vehicle and non-departure are called the Great Vehicle,
All are completely equal, and thus one sets out.ğŸ”½This vehicle is neither in union

The most supreme tranquility.ğŸ”½All ordinary person dharmas,
All Å›rÄvaka dharmas,

aspirationlessness, and non-action,
It is neither far nor near, and all are unobtainable.ğŸ”½In the dharmas of disgust, detachment, and cessation,
The dharmas of nirvana and tranquility,
It is neither far nor near, and all are unobtainable.
This vehicle, this armor, and this path are without grasping,
Unsurpassed and unmoving, ultimately unobtainable.ğŸ”½The intrinsic nature of all dharmas,

Because the nature of dharmas is empty.

Their nature is also like this.
In all dharmas, the characteristics of self-nature cannot be obtained,ğŸ”½In the dharmas without the characteristics of self-nature,
I briefly reveal.
In all dharmas, all the characteristics of self-nature,
In this way, I say that ultimately nothing exists.
This vehicle, this path, and the nature of the armor,
When seeking for their verbal expression, ultimately they too do not exist.
Because verbal expression does not exist, this is the characteristic of the marvelous,
Within those verbal expressions, the characteristics of words also do not exist.
All dharmas are immeasurable, without superiority, and boundless,
All are unfathomable, therefore the Dharma is unsurpassed.
This vehicle, this armor, and this path are also like this,
Within those signless characteristics, one should accordingly enter in this way.
In order to cause sentient beings to thoroughly know and diligently cultivate,
Swiftly attaining the light of the Dharma, therefore I speak in this way.
All dharmas are without language, all are inexpressible,
Within those dharmas, all should accordingly enter.
Because the Dharma is beyond words, one should practice accordingly.
In practice, there is no practice at all, all dharmas are without practice.
Without seeking, yet delighting in seeking; without practice, yet following practice.
Thus, one who practices in this way does not contemplate the meaning.
You should now practice in accordance with the true meaning,
Do not follow along with sounds and words.
If one can attain non-attachment to sounds and words,
One will then practice in accordance with the meaning, being one who seeks the meaning.
What is called the meaning should be understood as secret speech,
With faith and non-discrimination, this is practicing in accordance with the meaning.
Clearly understanding such meaning, one is able to [understand] secret speech,
Without grasping, without attachment, not practicing, not following along.
If there is one who follows along, they will then follow along with grasping,
If there is no following, then all do not follow.
By this right mindfulness, one is far removed from following,
Neither enlightenment nor samsara are mutually related.
There is no thought of them, and no thought is right thought.
Because of the purity of thought, it is said to be pure.
If one practices differently, one is far removed from the unsurpassed Dharma.
You should practice this meaning as it is taught.
If one follows language, then one follows sound,
Not transcending it, one is the same as worldly dharmas.
Sound and words should not be followed,
One should know the true meaning, which is followed without practice.
The true meaning is without sound, and also without words,
Because it transcends language, it is called the true meaning.
This meaning should be followed in practice, and in practice there is nothing to be found.
Because of the cessation of practice, it is called the true meaning.
Within the true meaning, non-practice is taken as practice.
This is non-retrogression, not abandoning the armor.
In accordance with the great armor, the Great Vehicle, and the Great Way,
One proceeds to the place of peace and happiness, benefiting all sentient beings.
These methods of peace and security, I now explain for you.
You should practice in accordance with the meaning, and you will be able to cut off your doubts and confusion.
If one rides this vehicle, having ridden it one should set out.
Quickly proceed to great enlightenment, and presently realize unsurpassed awakening.
On this supreme vehicle, not riding is the swift riding.
The meaning of the path and the armor is also like this.
For those who diligently cultivate this unsurpassed Dharma,
Those sentient beings will be protected and remembered by the Buddha.
In the frightening times to come, you should expound this Dharma,
And be a great benefactor to all sentient beings.
In the frightening times to come, if you can expound this Dharma,
The unsurpassed merit you will generate will be immeasurable.
Boundless Wisdom!
The armor worn by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is called the Great Victory, also called Boundless Victory, and also called Great Adornment.
The vehicle they ride is called the Great Caravan, also called Boundless Light, and also called Wonderful Adornment.
The path they tread is called the Provisioning of Immeasurable Adornments, also called the Provisioning of Immeasurable Skillful Means.
By this path, all good men and women set out for anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Moreover, Boundless Wisdom!

In the distant past, countless eons ago, there was a buddha who appeared in the world, named Sandalwood Fragrance Light TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One.
The eon was named Lightning Light, and the country was named Light.

At that time, the land of that realm was as flat as the palm of a hand, without any impurities such as tiles, pebbles, or thorns. Golden sand and silver sand were arranged in rows throughout the country, delighting those who saw it.

At that time, the four continents were each two hundred million yojanas wide. Each continent had forty-eight thousand great cities. Each city was ten yojanas wide and twenty yojanas long, with surrounding walls that were majestic and lofty.
In each city, eight koá¹­is of people lived there. Ten thousand villages and one thousand gardens surrounded and adorned it.
And this country is further adorned with various flower trees, fruit trees, fragrant trees, clothing trees, delicious trees, and diamond trees interspersed.
The banks of the ponds, springs, and streams are straight, filled with the eight kinds of pure water, and adorned with blue, red, and white lotus flowers.
The lifespan of that TathÄgata Candana-gandha-prabhÄsa was sixty-eight koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of years, and he had a retinue of sixty koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of Å›rÄvakas.

At that time, the people were well-favored, peaceful and happy, with little greed, anger, and delusion, easy to teach and able to fully understand the nature and characteristics of all dharmas with little instruction.
Anantamati!
At that time, there was a wheel-turning king named SarvÄrthasiddha, who possessed the seven treasures and ruled over the four continents.
In that JambudvÄ«pa there was a great city, forty yojanas long and wide, with a thriving population, peaceful and prosperous.
Inside the royal palace it was five yojanas wide, adorned with the seven treasures, with marvelous tÄla trees hanging with bells, and a golden net covering above.

The king's main hall was made entirely of dark blue lapis lazuli, one yojana wide on all four sides with a thousand pillars. Above the hall there were a thousand towers, lofty and majestic, adorned with various treasures.
In front of the hall there was a great fragrant pond, clear all around, and beside it there were sixteen small fragrant light ponds made of the seven treasures, arranged in a circle.
Between each pond flowed channels and rapids, producing wonderful sounds like playing various kinds of music.

One small pond had eight flights of stairs, and the fragrant light pond had thirty-two flights of stairs. Each flight of stairs was made entirely of gold, with rows of jeweled trees and jeweled nets covering above. The supreme fragrance filled the city, thus the pond was named Fragrant Light.
Infinite Wisdom!
That wheel-turning king had four chief consorts:
One was named Infinite Sound, the second was named Virtuous Sound, the third was named Various Wonderful Sounds, and the fourth was named Goose King Sound.
Each of the chief consorts had two sons:

One was named Not Empty Victorious, the second was named Virtuous Victorious, the third was named Dragon Victorious, the fourth was named Victorious Sound, the fifth was named Wonderful Sound, the sixth was named Brahma Sound, the seventh was named Victorious Cloud, and the eighth was named Cloud Sound.
There were six koá¹­is of court ladies and ten thousand princes.
At that time, the king was amusing and playing with his retinue in the inner palace when he suddenly saw a TathÄgata's sublime physical body in the sky.
At that time, the TathÄgata immediately said to the king:
'Great King!

You should don the unsurpassed armor, ride the unsurpassed vehicle, and set out for supreme perfect enlightenment. Give the medicine of wisdom to all beings, and do not be attached to the five desires of humans and gods.
This great armor can bring forth unsurpassed bliss, and this unsurpassed vehicle can lead one into the unsurpassed garden. Those who enter here will never turn back.
All the various desires of humans and gods are impermanent, subject to change and decay, their power does not last long, and they quickly perish.'
Infinite Wisdom!

At that time, when King SarvÄrthasiddha heard this, he said to the TathÄgata:ğŸ”½'Who can show this great armor, so that one may adorn oneself with such armor?ğŸ”½Who can show this great vehicle, so that one may ride and drive such a great vehicle?
Who can show this great path, so that one may set out on such a great path?'
At that time, the TathÄgata told King SarvÄrthasiddha:

'Great King, you should know that there is a TathÄgata named Candanagandhottama. You should go to him. He will expound this Dharma for you, don the great armor, ride the Great Vehicle, and enter the Great Way.'
At that time, after the TathÄgata had spoken thus, he suddenly disappeared.
Anantamati!

At that time, when King SarvÄrthasiddha saw this, he was terrified and his hair stood on end. He gave rise to an extraordinary mind and then became afraid, not delighting in the various sensual pleasures of humans and gods. He became disgusted with all conditioned activities and sought the great armor, the Great Vehicle, and the Great Way. He then went together with his eight sons, four wives, and other children, attendants, and retinue to where the TathÄgata Candanagandhottama was.

Having arrived there, together with his retinue he respectfully made prostrations, bowed his head at the feet of the Buddha, and scattered a hundred dhanus of seven-jeweled flowers over the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One. He also offered immeasurable branches to the TathÄgata and the assembly of Å›rÄvakas, and for ten thousand years he made offerings to them with all kinds of comfortable provisions.
After this, he abandoned his royal status and together with his retinue left home to become renunciants in the teachings of the TathÄgata Candana-gandha-prabhÄsa.
Anantamati!
